abstract.p: The tip clearance, backface clearance, and backface cavity clearance flows in deeply scalloped radial turbines are numerically investigated in this article. The secondary flow structures in the rotor passage with the three clearance flows are shown and their influences on the distribution of aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet are analyzed. It is found that the migration of the tip clearance flow is constrained near the tip corner, and the region influenced by the tip clearance flow is mainly located at the upper span. With the largest mass flow rate, the tip clearance flow has the greatest impact on the outlet parameters among the three clearance flows. The backface clearance flow enters the mainstream from the blade backface and migrates toward the blade tip due to the centrifugal force. And it mainly affects the distribution of outlet parameters at the mid-span. The backface cavity clearance flow is injected into the mainstream from the disc rim. It moves toward the blade tip and stays close to the suction surface. With the smallest mass flow rate, the impact of the backface cavity clearance flow on the outlet parameters is the lowest.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
In radial turbines, the clearance flows reduce the turbine efficiency and cause a complex secondary flow structure in the rotor passage. Deeply scalloped radial turbine rotors (Figure 1(c)), which are widely used in modern microturbines, ‘scallop’ their disc to reduce centrifugal stress, and an additional clearance flow (backface clearance flow) is introduced. Therefore, there are three clearance flows in deeply scalloped radial turbines, they are tip clearance flow, backface clearance flow, and backface cavity clearance flow. Figure 1.
Schematic of the radial turbines with three design schemes: (a) scheme 1 (baseline, no scallop, and no clearance); (b) scheme 2 (scalloped, RD = 0.8); and (c) scheme 3 (deeply scalloped, RD = 0.64).

The tip clearance flow exists in most of the radial turbines and it has been studied by many researchers. Futral and Holeski1 indicated that the efficiency penalty due to the tip clearance at the outlet was 10 times larger than that at the inlet. Dambach and co-workers2,3 measured the detailed velocity and pressure fields in the tip clearance of a radial turbine. It was concluded that, due to the reduced intensity of the scraping flow, the leakage flow rate and, therefore, the leakage loss increased drastically in the outlet section of the blade, which successfully explained the conclusion drawn by Futral and Holeski.1 The flow field and secondary flow structure in radial turbines with the tip clearance flow can also be seen in previous works.4–6

In deeply scalloped radial turbines, as mentioned above, an additional clearance (backface clearance) is introduced. The backface clearance is usually the largest clearance in the turbine, hence, the corresponding loss is considerable. Simonyi and Boyle7 indicated that the efficiency penalty due to the backface clearance was nearly 60% of the total clearance losses. A similar conclusion was also drawn by Tirres8 when he predicted the performance of the solid version of a cooled radial rotor, and it was shown that the backface clearance loss for the rotor accounted for 79% of the total clearance losses. Larosiliere9 simulated the backface clearance flow in a deeply scalloped radial turbine. The author presented entropy contours and velocity vectors at different quasi-normal planes, and showed the backface clearance leakage vortex. He et al.10 presented an aerothermal investigation of the backface clearance flow in a deeply scalloped radial turbine. The velocity field and heat transfer coefficient distribution in the backface clearance were shown and analyzed.

In microturbines, sufficient sealing flow is needed to be channeled from the compressor to the turbine through the backface cavity clearance. This sealing flow prevents hot gas ingestion and maintains acceptable disc temperature, which is very important for the radial turbine rotor.11,12 The efficiency penalty due to the cavity clearance flow is also considerable. There was a reduction in efficiency of 1% with 1% backface cavity flow injected as indicated by Hiett and Johnston13 and Rogo.14

All the above studies focus on just one clearance flow in radial turbines. And there is little literature concerning all the three clearance flows, which exist widely in deeply scalloped radial turbines. The three clearance flows can greatly affect the secondary flow structure and the outlet flow field of the turbine. This article investigates the tip clearance, backface clearance, and backface cavity clearance flows in deeply scalloped radial turbines, the secondary flow structures in the rotor passage with the three clearance flows are analyzed, and their influences on the distribution of aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet are also discussed.

sec.title: Numerical method
sec.p:
Figure 1 shows the schematic of the radial turbines and three design schemes are discussed in this article. The radial turbine is designed for a microturbine, the blade and vane profiles for the three schemes are same. The baseline turbine (scheme 1) has no scallop and clearance, which is often used during the turbine design process. In order to reduce the rotor weight and centrifugal stress, the rotor disc is scalloped (schemes 2 and 3 in Figure 1(b) and (c), respectively). Compared with scheme 2, the rotor disc for scheme 3 is scalloped deeper and the centrifugal stress can be reduced significantly. However, for scheme 3, the hub profile is less smooth and the length of the backface clearance is larger. Therefore, for schemes 2 and 3, the influences of the clearance flows are different. In order to evaluate the impact of each clearance flow, the three clearance flows are included in schemes 2 and 3 step-by-step, and the detailed procedures are listed in Table 1. In the following sections, the new step is compared with the old step to discuss the influence of each clearance flow. For schemes 2 and 3, the normalized tip clearance height is 6% at the inlet (TC1 = 6%) and 0.8% at the outlet (TC2 = 0.8%). The normalized backface clearance height is 8% (BC = 8%) and the normalized backface cavity clearance height is 1% (CC = 1%). The definition of normalized clearance height can be seen in the notation. The clearance heights are the typical value of deeply scalloped radial turbines for microturbines. Table 1.
The clearance flows included at each step.
Step Schemes (S) Clearance flows included
1 S1 Baseline, no clearance flow
2 S2_TC Include tip clearance flow only
3 S2/S3_TC_BC Include tip clearance and backface clearance flows
4 S2/S3_TC_BC_CC Include all of the three clearance flows

Structured meshes are generated using ANSYS ICEM. The computational domain for the radial turbine consists of one stator vane and one rotor blade with backface cavity. To insure mesh independence, the stator passage requires ∼0.5 million cells, the rotor passage requires ∼1.5 million cells, and the backface cavity requires ∼0.4 million cells. The total cell number is about 2.4 million. Meshes are generated in the clearance regions where the average Y+ is about 1. The numbers of cells in the tip and backface clearance regions are ∼0.14 million and ∼0.1 million, respectively. Figure 2 shows the meshes of the radial turbine with the three clearances. The coarse meshes are presented for better visualization. Figure 2.
Meshes of the deeply scalloped radial turbine.

The calculations are performed using ANSYS CFX, and the solutions are obtained by solving Navier–Stokes equations. The stator inlet is located at 0.5 chords upstream of the stator leading edge, and the rotor outlet is located at 0.6 chords downstream of the rotor trailing edge. At the stator inlet, total pressure (375.6 kPa) and total temperature (1150 K) are specified along with a radial flow angle (0°) and a medium turbulence intensity (5%). At the backface cavity inlet, total temperature (575 K) and mass flow (MR = 1%) are specified. At the rotor outlet, average static pressure (96 kPa) is specified. The rotational periodic boundary condition is imposed on the periodic boundaries. And the non-slip and adiabatic conditions are applied on the blades and walls. The stator is in stationary domain, the rotor and the backface cavity are in rotating domain. The connection option of the stator and rotor domains is ‘stage’ which performs a circumferential averaging of the fluxes through bands on the stator and rotor domain interface. A counter-rotating wall condition is specified for the tip and backface casings. In this case, the tip and backface casings are stationary in the absolute coordinate system, whereas in the rotating coordinate system, they move with an angular velocity (ω) in the counter-rotating direction and the relative casing motion to the blade is simulated. The low Reynolds number shear stress transport (SST) k–ω turbulence model, which gives highly accurate prediction of the flow separation, is used during the simulation.

In order to evaluate the ability of CFX to simulate the flow field at the outlet of deeply scalloped radial turbines, computational fluid dynamics (CFD) verification was performed in He et al.10 The turbine geometry and the experimental data were obtained in the NASA report.15 The mesh generations and computational settings were similar to that using in this article. The comparison of aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet is presented in Figure 3. The spanwise distribution of aerodynamic parameters is obtained by performing a circumferential averaging of the variables at the constant span. And the calculation of the spanwise efficiency is based on the same constant span bands of the stator inlet and rotor outlet. The maximum numerical errors for the CFD verification are listed in Table 2 and the experimental data is the standard value (standard) for comparison. In order to evaluate the influence of the backface clearance flow on the aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet, the calculation results with backface clearance flow (CFD) and without backface clearance flow (CFDNBC) are presented. For the case with the backface clearance flow (CFD), there is a shift between the calculated results and the experimental data, especially for the total temperature and efficiency (Figure 3(b) and (d)). This may be due to some idealizing assumptions during the CFD procedure, such as the circumferential average treatment for the stator–rotor connection interface, the adiabatic wall, and the smooth passage profile. However, the distribution trend of the calculated results agrees well with the experimental data. For the case without the backface clearance flow (CFDNBC), the calculated total temperature and efficiency distributions have larger errors especially at the mid-span. CFX successfully captures the influence of the backface clearance flow on the distribution trend of the aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet, which could provide a good reference for the following study. sec.title: Turbine performance for scheme 1
sec.p:
The deeply scalloped radial turbine is designed for a microturbine. The turbine design values are obtained from the cycle analysis and they are listed in Table 3. The design rules are based on the previous works13,16–19 and the one-dimensional (1D) design results are listed in Table 4. Figure 4 shows the turbine blade velocity triangles and loading. One can see that the flow in the stator and rotor passages is subsonic and the blade loading is approximately constant along the meridional distance. Figure 5 shows the calculated distribution of aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet (0.6 chords downstream of the rotor trailing edge) for scheme 1 (no clearance flow). The spanwise distribution of aerodynamic parameters is obtained by performing a circumferential averaging of the variables at the constant span. And the calculation of the spanwise efficiency is based on the same constant span bands of the stator inlet and rotor outlet. There is an overturning region at the lower span location and an underturning region at the upper span location (Figure 5(b)), and this flow pattern was also observed in McLean et al.20 Meanwhile, the calculated efficiency is generally higher than the design value (Figure 5(c)). The clearance flows in the deeply scalloped radial turbine can locally overturn or underturn the flow and decrease the turbine efficiency;20 therefore, the distribution of aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet will be different from that without clearance flow. In the following sections, the influence of the three clearance flows will be discussed. Figure 4.

sec.title: Tip clearance flow in the turbine
sec.p:
The tip clearance flow exists widely in radial turbines and its influence is discussed in this section. Figure 6 shows the normalized entropy (s/s0) contour at the traverse planes for scheme 2 (S2_TC). The clearance flow interacts with the mainstream, which increases mixing loss and entropy. Therefore, the fluid with high entropy is considered to be the clearance flows. In Figure 6, one can see that the intensity of the tip clearance flow increases along the streamwise direction, which results in a large high-entropy zone in the outlet section of the blade. Influenced by the centrifugal force, the migration of the tip clearance flow is constrained near the tip corner. Figure 6.
Entropy contour at the traverse planes (S2_TC).

Figure 7 shows the influence of the tip clearance flow on the aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet. Compared with the no clearance case, the tip clearance flow decreases the total pressure at the upper span location (Figure 7(a)). A large mixing loss is induced by the interaction between the leakage flow and the mainstream (Figure 6), and the total pressure is reduced. The flow angle is also reduced at the upper span location (Figure 7(b)), which is due to the underturning effect of the tip clearance flow. Meanwhile, in the upper-span region, due to the high intensity of the tip clearance flow, the turbine efficiency decreases drastically. The region influenced by the tip clearance flow is mainly located at the upper span and the aerodynamic parameters do not change much in the lower-span region. Figure 7.
Influence of the tip clearance flow on the aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet: (a) total pressure; (b) absolute flow angle; and (c) efficiency.

sec.title: Backface clearance flow in the turbine
sec.p:
In order to reduce weight and centrifugal stress, the rotor disc of the radial turbine is ‘scalloped’ and an additional clearance is introduced (backface clearance). The mass flow rates of the tip clearance and the backface clearance flows (mc/m) are listed in Table 5. One can see that the mass flow rate of the backface clearance flow is much smaller than that of the tip clearance flow. This is attributable to two causes. First, the blade loading at hub is lower than that at shroud (Figure 4(b)), hence, the pressure-driven leakage flow in the backface clearance is smaller. Second, the length of the backface clearance is smaller than that of the tip clearance (Figure 1(b) and (c)), which results in a relatively smaller leakage flow rate in the backface clearance.21 Table 5.

Backface clearance flow (S3) 2.6

Figure 8 shows the normalized entropy (s/s0) contour at the traverse planes with both the tip and backface clearance flows (S3_TC_BC). One can see that the intensity of the backface clearance flow is lower than that of the tip clearance flow, which is due to the smaller leakage flow rate (Table 5). However, instead of flowing near the hub corner, the backface clearance flow migrates toward the blade tip due to the influence of the centrifugal force. During the migration along the streamwise direction, the backface clearance flow is dissipated quickly. Figure 8.
Entropy contour at the traverse planes (S3_TC_BC).

Figure 9 shows the influence of the backface clearance flow on the aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet for schemes 2 and 3, respectively. Although the backface clearance flow is dissipated quickly along the streamwise direction, its impact on the outlet parameters is considerable. Compared with the tip clearance flow, the region influenced by the backface clearance flow is mainly located at the mid-span. In the case of scheme 3, compared with the no backface clearance case (S3_TC), the backface clearance flow (S3_TC_BC) decreases the total pressure in the mid-span region. As mentioned above, this is due to the interaction between the backface clearance flow and the mainstream, and the efficiency is also reduced in this region. Meanwhile, the backface clearance flow decreases the flow angle at the upper span location (Span > 0.5), and increases it at the lower span location (Span < 0.5), which can be seen in Figure 9(e). In the case of scheme 2, due to the smaller backface clearance length and, therefore, the less leakage flow rate (Table 5), the influence of the backface clearance flow is smaller than scheme 3. Figure 9.
Influence of the backface clearance flow on the aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet for schemes 2 and 3, respectively: (a) total pressure (S2); (b) absolute flow angle (S2); (c) efficiency (S2); (d) total pressure (S3); (e) absolute flow angle (S3); (f) efficiency (S3); (g) total pressure (S2, S3); (h) absolute flow angle (S2, S3); and (i) efficiency (S2, S3).

As can be seen in Figure 1, the disc radius ratio (RD) for scheme 2 is larger than that for scheme 3, and their meridional geometries are different, especially at hub. For scheme 3, the thicknesses and losses of the boundary layer increase near the disc rim, which may influence the flow near the hub. Figure 10 shows the blade surface pressure distribution at hub for schemes 2 and 3, respectively. Compared with scheme 2 (S2_TC), the pressure at the suction side for scheme 3 (S3_TC) is reduced at about 30% meridional distance (disc rim). However, as can be seen in Figure 9(g) to (i), there is no significant difference in the distribution of aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet between scheme 2 (S2_TC) and scheme 3 (S3_TC), which implies that the meridional geometry has limited influence on the outlet parameters. Figure 10.
Influence of the meridional geometry on the blade surface pressure distribution at hub.

sec.title: Cavity clearance flow in the turbine
sec.p:
In microturbines, sufficient backface cavity clearance flow is injected to prevent hot gas ingestion and maintain acceptable disc temperature for the radial turbine. Figure 11 shows the flow structure of the cavity clearance flow in the radial turbine. The red lines are the 3D streamlines of the cavity clearance flow. One can see that the cavity clearance flow is injected into the cavity at the lower radial position, swirled by the rotation of the disc in the backface cavity, and then mixed into the mainstream. After impinging on the root corner of the blade suction surface (SS), the cavity clearance flow is divided into two branches. The suction side branch of the clearance flow (FS) stays close to the SS due to the circumferential pressure gradient, and moves toward the blade tip under the influence of the centrifugal force. The pressure side branch of the clearance flow (FP) flows through the backface clearance in the lower radial region and migrates to the SS of the next blade. These two branches of the clearance flows finally merge together at the rotor outlet. Figure 11.
Backface cavity clearance flow in the turbine.

Figure 12 shows the influence of the backface cavity clearance flow on the aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet for schemes 2 and 3, respectively. The definition of turbine efficiency with cavity clearance flow can be seen in the notation. With the injection of the cavity clearance flow (S2/S3_TC_BC_CC), the total pressure decreases and the flow angle increases in the upper-span region. However, in the lower-span region, the total pressure increases and the flow angle does not change much. Meanwhile, the efficiency decreases at both the upper (Span = 0.8) and lower (Span = 0.1) span locations. Figure 12.
Influence of the backface cavity clearance flow on the aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet for schemes 2 and 3, respectively: (a) total pressure (S2); (b) absolute flow angle (S2); (c) efficiency (S2); (d) total pressure (S3); (e) absolute flow angle (S3); and (f) efficiency (S3).

The typical mass flow rate of the backface cavity clearance flow is about 1% (MR = 1%) in microturbines.14 As can be seen in Table 5, the mass flow rate of the cavity clearance flow is relatively lower compared with that of the tip and backface clearance flows. Therefore, the influence of the backface cavity clearance flow on the aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet is smallest among the three clearance flows.

sec.title: Three clearance flows in the turbine
sec.p:
Figure 13 shows the influence of the three clearance flows on the aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet. One can see that, influenced by the tip clearance, backface clearance, and backface cavity clearance flows, the distribution of aerodynamic parameters at the turbine rotor outlet, especially the distribution of efficiency, is quite different from that without clearance flow. The maximum efficiency reduction is about 8.4% and the overall efficiency penalty is about 4% (Figure 13(c)). Meanwhile, there is an increase in flow underturning at the upper span location due to the overall impact of the clearance flows (Figure 13(b)). Figure 13.
Influence of the three clearance flows on the aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet: (a) total pressure; (b) absolute flow angle; and (c) efficiency.

Table 6 summarizes the maximum change of the aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet due to the tip clearance, backface clearance, and backface cavity clearance flows, respectively. And the change is obtained by calculating the difference between the parameters with and without clearance flow at the same span. One can see that, with the largest leakage flow rate, the tip clearance flow has the greatest impact on the aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet. The maximum efficiency penalty due to the tip clearance flow is about 7.7%, and that is close to the maximum efficiency penalty caused by the combined effect of the three clearance flows (8.4%). The maximum impact of the backface clearance flow on the total pressure and flow angle is similar to that of the tip clearance flow, whereas the efficiency penalty is relatively smaller. The backface cavity clearance flow has the smallest impact on the aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet among the three clearance flows. Table 6.

The secondary flow structure in the rotor passage of the deeply scalloped radial turbine is shown in Figure 14. As indicated in Zangeneh et al.,22 there are two scraping flows near the tip and backface casings. These scraping flows are caused by the relative casing motion and the pressure gradient from the pressure surface (PS) to the SS. Meanwhile, there is a spanwise secondary flow near the SS due to the influence of the centrifugal force. In deeply scalloped radial turbines, three clearance flows are introduced. In the blade inlet section (A–A traverse plane), there are two clearance leakage vortexes in the rotor passage. The tip and backface leakage vortexes are located near the tip casing and the backface casing corners, respectively. In the blade outlet section (B–B traverse plane), the migration of the tip leakage vortex is constrained near the tip corner, whereas the backface leakage vortex migrates toward the blade tip. The tip and backface leakage vortexes do not mix with each other at the rotor outlet. Meanwhile, in the blade outlet section, the backface cavity clearance flow is injected. The cavity clearance flow stays close to the SS and migrates toward the blade tip. Figure 14.
Schematic of the secondary flow structure in the deeply scalloped radial turbine.

The three clearance flows are the major source of secondary flows in deeply scalloped radial turbines, and they have a great impact on the efficiency distribution at the rotor outlet. Therefore, it is necessary to analyze the turbine flow field taking account of all the three clearance flows.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
This article investigates the clearance flows in deeply scalloped radial turbines with three design schemes. The secondary flow structures in the rotor passage with the clearance flows are shown and their influences on the aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet are analyzed. And the following conclusions can be drawn.
Influenced by the centrifugal force, the migration of the tip clearance flow is constrained near the tip corner. The tip clearance flow increases the flow underturning, decreases the total pressure and efficiency in the upper-span region (Span > 0.7), whereas the outlet parameters in the lower-span region (Span < 0.7) remain nearly unchanged. Among the three clearance flows, the tip clearance flow has the greatest impact on the aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet and the maximum efficiency penalty is about 7.7%.
The backface clearance flow enters the mainstream from the blade backface, and moves toward the blade tip due to the centrifugal force. The backface clearance flow decreases the total pressure and efficiency in the mid-span region. Meanwhile, it decreases the flow angle in the upper-span region (Span > 0.5), and increases it in the lower-span region (Span < 0.5). With a larger backface clearance length and, therefore, a larger leakage flow rate, scheme 3 has a greater impact on the aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet than scheme 2. The maximum impact of the backface clearance flow on the total pressure and flow angle is similar to that of the tip clearance flow, whereas the efficiency penalty is relatively smaller.
The backface cavity clearance flow is injected into the mainstream from the disc rim. It migrates toward the blade tip and stays close to the SS. With the smallest mass flow rate, the cavity clearance flow has the lowest impact on the aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet.
Due to the overall impact of the three clearance flows, the distribution of aerodynamic parameters at the rotor outlet, especially the distribution of efficiency, is quite different from that without clearance flow. The three clearance flows are the major source of secondary flows in deeply scalloped radial turbines. Therefore, it is necessary to analyze the turbine flow field taking account of all the three clearance flows.
